choices.text: Thiazides
Beta adrenergic blocker
ACE inhibitor
Diazoxide

questions.text: In a patient with concomitant diabetes, anti-hypertensive agent of choice is?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) ACE inhibitor

 

Option C:

 

ACE inhibitors are the preferred choice for hypertensive patients with diabetes because they have protective effects on the kidneys, which are often compromised in diabetic patients. They reduce blood pressure and decrease the progression of diabetic nephropathy by reducing intraglomerular pressure and proteinuria.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Thiazides: Thiazide diuretics are effective antihypertensive agents but can affect carbohydrate metabolism and are not the first choice in patients with diabetes, as they can potentially worsen glycemic control.

 

Option B. Beta adrenergic blocker: Beta-blockers can mask symptoms of hypoglycemia and may also affect lipid metabolism. Although they are effective for blood pressure control, they are not typically the first-line choice in diabetic patients unless there are other compelling indications such as heart failure or post-myocardial infarction.

 

Option D. Diazoxide: Diazoxide is a vasodilator that can actually increase blood sugar levels by inhibiting insulin release from the pancreas. It is not used for routine treatment of hypertension and is certainly not the drug of choice in patients with diabetes.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The educational goal is to understand the appropriate choice of antihypertensive medication in patients with diabetes. ACE inhibitors offer renal protection and do not worsen glycemic control, making them a superior option for this patient population. Other properties of ACE inhibitors are also important for entrance exams.

 

Properties of ACE inhibitors

 

C - Cough

 

A - Angioedema

 

P - Prodrugs (except captopril and Lisinopril)

 

T - Taste disturbances

 

O - Orthostatic hypotension (when combined with diuretics)

 

P - Pregnancy (contra- indicated)

 

R - bilateral Renal artery stenosis (contra-indicated)

 

I - Increased K+ (contra-indicated)

 

L - Lower the risk of diabetic nephropathy (Preferred drug in diabetic patients with hypertension)

choices.text: Quinidine
Amiodarone
Lignocaine
Phenytoin

questions.text: Which of the following is the drug of choice for digoxin induced ventricular tachyarrhythmias?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Lignocaine 

 

Option C:

 

Lignocaine is the drug of choice for treating ventricular tachyarrhythmias induced by digoxin toxicity. It works by stabilizing the cardiac membrane and is effective in treating digoxin-induced arrhythmias without further inhibiting the AV conduction, which is often already compromised in digoxin toxicity. Its use in this context is based on its ability to selectively target the arrhythmogenic effects without exacerbating the digoxin effect on the AV node.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Quinidine: Quinidine is an antiarrhythmic that can increase serum digoxin levels and is contraindicated in digoxin-induced arrhythmias because it may exacerbate toxicity.

 

Option B. Amiodarone: While amiodarone is a versatile antiarrhythmic agent used in various types of arrhythmias, it can interact with digoxin and increase its levels, potentially worsening toxicity.

 

Option D. Phenytoin: Phenytoin is effective for ventricular arrhythmias, especially in the context of acute myocardial infarction, but it is not the first choice for digoxin-induced arrhythmias. It can be used if lignocaine is not available or contraindicated.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The educational goal is to understand the appropriate management of digoxin-induced ventricular tachyarrhythmias. Recognizing lignocaine as the drug of choice in this scenario is critical for effectively addressing the cardiac toxicity associated with digoxin overdose, minimizing the risk of further cardiac complications.

choices.text: Carvedilol
Spironolactone
Nitroglycerine
Digoxin

questions.text: A 45-year-old man presents with NYHA Class III breathlessness with a serum creatinine of 2.5 mg/dL and potassium level of 5.5 mEq/L. Which of the following drug is contraindicated?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Spironolactone

 

Option B:

 

Spironolactone is contraindicated in this patient due to the presence of renal failure (as indicated by a serum creatinine of 2.5 mg/dL, where normal is less than 1 mg/dL) and higher normal levels of serum potassium (5.5 mEq/L, where normal range is 3.5–5.5 mEq/L). Spironolactone is a potassium-sparing diuretic and aldosterone antagonist which is beneficial in chronic heart failure (CHF) patients, particularly those with hypokalemia, as it prevents cardiac remodeling. However, it is contraindicated in the presence of deranged renal function because it could lead to the development of severe hyperkalemia. This risk remains even when the serum potassium level is high normal.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Carvedilol: Incorrect as beta blockers like carvedilol are indicated in CHF and can reduce mortality. They should be started at a very low dose and gradually titrated to the target dose.

 

Option C. Nitroglycerine: Incorrect because nitroglycerine is a vasodilator that can help reduce the workload of the heart and provide symptomatic relief in CHF.

 

Option D. Digoxin: Incorrect as digoxin is an oral inotropic agent that can be used in chronic CHF to improve symptoms and possibly exercise capacity. Although it is excreted by kidneys but it can be used in renal failure after dose adjustment.

 

Educational objective:

 

In patients with CHF and compromised renal function or elevated serum potassium levels, potassium-sparing diuretics like spironolactone should be avoided due to the increased risk of severe hyperkalemia.

choices.text: Flecainide
Tocainide
Procainamide
Ibutilide

questions.text: Identify the antiarrhythmic agent with the following mechanism of action?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Flecainide

 

Option A:

 

The graph shows an action potential of a cardiac myocyte with a marked block of sodium channels and no change in the repolarization phase. This description is consistent with the action of Class IC antiarrhythmic drugs, which significantly slow the conduction of the cardiac impulse through the myocardium by blocking sodium channels without affecting the duration of the action potential. Flecainide is a Class IC antiarrhythmic drug that exhibits a marked blockade of sodium channels, which slows conduction throughout the heart. It does not significantly prolong the action potential or affect repolarization, which is consistent with the graph shown.

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. Tocainide: Tocainide is a Class IB antiarrhythmic agent. Class IB drugs tend to shorten the action potential duration rather than having no change in repolarization.

 

Option C. Procainamide: Procainamide is a Class IA antiarrhythmic agent that not only blocks sodium channels but also has a moderate effect on repolarization, leading to a slight prolongation of the action potential, which is not depicted in the graph.

 

Option D. Ibutilide: Ibutilide is a Class III antiarrhythmic drug that acts by prolonging repolarization through potassium channel blockade, which would lengthen the action potential, contrary to what is shown in the graph.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The educational goal is to recognize the electrophysiologic profiles of different classes of antiarrhythmic drugs. Class IC antiarrhythmics like flecainide are characterized by their potent sodium channel-blocking effects with minimal impact on the duration of the action potential. Understanding these properties is important for the appropriate selection and use of antiarrhythmic drugs in clinical practice.

choices.text: Pregnancy induced hypertension
Renovascular hypertension
First line agent in hypertension
Refractory hypertension

questions.text: Alpha methyldopa is primarily used for treatment of:
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Pregnancy induced hypertension

 

Option A:

 

Alpha methyldopa is primarily utilized for managing hypertension during pregnancy. It is considered safe for use in pregnant women when blood pressure control is necessary. As a prodrug, methyldopa is metabolized to its active form, which acts as an agonist at alpha-2 adrenergic receptors in the brain. This action leads to a decrease in central sympathetic outflow, thereby lowering blood pressure. Its use in pregnancy-induced hypertension is due to its efficacy and safety profile for both the mother and the fetus.

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. Renovascular hypertension: Incorrect as alpha methyldopa is not the first choice of treatment for renovascular hypertension.

 

Option C. First line agent in hypertension: Incorrect because alpha methyldopa is not commonly used as a first-line treatment for essential hypertension.

 

Option D. Refractory hypertension: Incorrect as alpha methyldopa is not typically reserved for refractory hypertension but could be used if other options are unsuitable.

 

Educational objective:

 

Alpha methyldopa is mainly used for the treatment of hypertension in pregnancy due to its efficacy and safety profile, acting through central mechanisms by stimulating alpha-2 adrenergic receptors.

choices.text: It causes direct relaxation of the blood vessels
It causes dilatation of both arteries and veins
Postural hypotension is not a common problem
It increases plasma renin activity

questions.text: Which of the following statements about hydralazine is not true?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) It causes dilatation of both arteries and veins

 

Option B:

 

Hydralazine primarily causes arteriolar dilation rather than venous dilation, which is why option b is not true. It works by a direct action on vascular smooth muscle, leading to vasodilation. This is believed to involve the release of nitric oxide (NO) and the opening of potassium channels. The dilatory effect of hydralazine is more pronounced in arteries, which is why it does not commonly cause postural hypotension—a condition usually associated with venous dilation.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Correct as hydralazine does cause direct relaxation of blood vessels, particularly arterioles.

 

Option C. Correct because postural hypotension is not a common problem with hydralazine, as it does not significantly dilate veins.

 

Option D. Correct as vasodilators like hydralazine can cause an increase in plasma renin activity due to compensatory mechanisms following a decrease in blood pressure, such as increased sympathetic activity.

 

Educational objective:

 

Hydralazine is an antihypertensive agent that predominantly causes arteriolar dilation, resulting in decreased blood pressure without significantly affecting veins or causing postural hypotension.

choices.text: It acts by causing a reduction in central sympathetic outflow
It increases LDL-cholesterol on prolonged use
Sedation and xerostomia are common side effects of clonidine
It can be combined with vasodilators

questions.text: All the following statements are true about the use of clonidine in the treatment of hypertension except:
questions.solution:
Ans. B) It increases LDL-cholesterol on prolonged use

 

Option B:

 

Clonidine does not increase LDL-cholesterol with prolonged use; in fact, it is known to decrease LDL and increase HDL-cholesterol. Clonidine is an alpha-2 adrenergic agonist that acts centrally to reduce sympathetic outflow, which in turn lowers blood pressure. It is effective when used alone or in combination with other antihypertensive agents, including vasodilators. Combining clonidine with vasodilators can be particularly beneficial because it can prevent the reflex increase in renin release that vasodilators often cause. Sedation and dry mouth (xerostomia) are indeed common side effects associated with clonidine use.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Correct as clonidine decreases central sympathetic outflow due to its alpha-2 agonist action.

 

Option C. Correct since sedation and xerostomia are well-documented side effects of clonidine.

 

Option D. Correct because clonidine can be combined with vasodilators to treat hypertension effectively.

 

Educational objective:

 

Clonidine, an alpha-2 agonist, is used in the treatment of hypertension, primarily by reducing central sympathetic outflow and not by increasing LDL-cholesterol; it actually tends to have a beneficial effect on cholesterol profiles.

choices.text: Atrial fibrillation
Bradycardia with AV block
Torsades de pointes
Tachycardia

questions.text: A patient was taking verapamil for PSVT prophylaxis. He was given propranolol for treatment of essential tremors. This combination can result in:
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Bradycardia with AV block

 

Option B:

 

Both propranolol and verapamil have negative chronotropic effects, meaning they decrease heart rate. Propranolol does this by blocking beta-1 adrenergic receptors, primarily affecting the sinoatrial (SA) node, while verapamil blocks L-type calcium channels, which are critical for impulse conduction through the atrioventricular (AV) node.

 

Adding verapamil to a patient already on propranolol increases the risk of additive effects on heart rate and conduction. This can lead to bradycardia, which is an abnormally slow heart rate, and in more severe cases, can progress to AV block. AV block occurs when the electrical conduction between the atria and ventricles is impaired, potentially leading to serious heart rhythm abnormalities and symptoms such as dizziness and fatigue.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Atrial fibrillation is not the most likely outcome of adding verapamil to propranolol therapy, although verapamil is sometimes used to control ventricular rate in patients with atrial fibrillation.

 

Option C. Torsades de pointes is a specific type of ventricular tachycardia often associated with a prolonged QT interval, which is not a typical side effect of either propranolol or verapamil.

 

Option D. Tachycardia, or increased heart rate, would be unlikely as both drugs work to slow the heart rate.

 

Educational Objectives:

 

Therefore, the most appropriate answer in the context of this clinical scenario is B. Bradycardia with AV block, considering the pharmacological actions of both propranolol and verapamil and the symptoms reported by the patient.

 

Ref: KDT 8th/160

choices.text: Aliskiren
Digoxin
Ivabradine
Valsartan

questions.text: A 72-year-old woman with a history of ischemic cardiomyopathy and left ventricular ejection fraction of 35%. She is NYHA class II in terms of symptoms. She is on lisinopril, carvedilol, and spironolactone. Her blood pressure is 102/82 mmHg, and heart rate is 80 bpm. Which of the following additional medications will further reduce her risk of hospitalization due to heart failure?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Ivabradine

 

Option C:

 

Ivabradine is an appropriate choice for this patient because it reduces heart rate without causing myocardial depression. It works by selectively inhibiting the If (funny) channels in the sinoatrial node, which are responsible for regulating heart rate. In patients with heart failure who are in sinus rhythm with a heart rate of 70 bpm or higher, despite optimal treatment with beta-blockers or those who are intolerant to beta-blockers, ivabradine has been shown to reduce hospitalization due to heart failure.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Aliskiren: Aliskiren is a direct renin inhibitor and is used to treat hypertension. While it can reduce blood pressure and has been studied in heart failure, it is not specifically indicated to reduce mortality in heart failure patients, particularly when already on optimal therapy with an ACE inhibitor, beta-blocker, and aldosterone antagonist.

 

Option B. Digoxin: Digoxin may help improve symptoms and reduce hospitalizations by increasing contractility and controlling heart rate, but it has not been shown to reduce mortality in heart failure patients.

 

Option D. Valsartan: The patient is already on lisinopril, an ACE inhibitor, which provides the mortality benefit of inhibiting the renin-angiotensin-aldosterone system (RAAS). Adding another RAAS inhibitor like valsartan, an ARB, without removing the ACE inhibitor is not typically recommended due to increased risk of adverse effects without additional mortality benefit.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Ivabradine can be used in certain heart failure patients with a high heart rate despite optimal standard therapy to further reduce the risk of heart failure-related morbidity. It is important to recognize the therapeutic benefits and limitations of additional heart failure treatments in the context of a patient's overall medical regimen and clinical status.

 

Ref: CMDT 2022 Pg 410

choices.text: Chlorthalidone
Triamterene
Spironolactone
Furosemide

questions.text: Preferred drug for the treatment of uncomplicated grade 2 hypertension in a 48-year-old man is?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Chlorthalidone

 

Option A:

 

Chlorthalidone is a thiazide-like diuretic that is often preferred for the initial treatment of hypertension, including grade 2 hypertension, which is defined as a systolic blood pressure of 140-159 mmHg or a diastolic blood pressure of 90-99 mmHg. Chlorthalidone helps to lower blood pressure by promoting the excretion of sodium and water, which reduces the volume of fluid in the blood vessels and lowers blood pressure. Its long half-life and evidence for reducing cardiovascular outcomes make it a suitable option for managing uncomplicated hypertension.

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. Triamterene: Triamterene is a potassium-sparing diuretic that is not typically used as first-line treatment for hypertension. It is often used in combination with other diuretics to prevent hypokalemia.

 

Option C. Spironolactone: Spironolactone is another potassium-sparing diuretic that also blocks the effects of aldosterone. While it can be used for hypertension, it is usually reserved for cases that are resistant to other treatments or for specific conditions like primary hyperaldosteronism.

 

Option D. Furosemide: Furosemide is a loop diuretic that is primarily used for the treatment of edema associated with heart failure or renal disease. It is not typically used as first-line treatment for uncomplicated hypertension due to its shorter duration of action and greater risk for electrolyte imbalances.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The educational goal is to identify the preferred initial treatment options for hypertension. Thiazide-like diuretics such as chlorthalidone are recommended as first-line therapy for most patients with hypertension due to their effectiveness in lowering blood pressure and reducing the risk of cardiovascular events.

 

FIRST LINE DRUGS FOR DIFFERENT PATIENTS WITH HYPERTENSION

choices.text: Spontaneous hydrolysis
Rapid metabolism by enzymes in the liver
Uptake in RBC and endothelial cells
Renal excretion

questions.text: Why does adenosine have a short half-life?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Uptake in RBC and endothelial cells

 

Option C:

 

Adenosine is known to be the shortest-acting anti-arrhythmic drug with a half-life of less than 10 seconds. Its brief duration of action is primarily attributed to its rapid uptake by red blood cells (RBCs) and endothelial cells. Once inside these cells, adenosine is quickly metabolized through two main pathways: phosphorylation and deamination. Phosphorylation, mediated by adenosine kinase, converts adenosine into adenosine monophosphate (AMP), which can then enter various pathways to be used as cellular energy. Deamination, on the other hand, is facilitated by the enzyme adenosine deaminase, leading to the production of inosine, which is further broken down into xanthine and eventually uric acid. The efficient intracellular metabolism of adenosine in these cells ensures that it does not remain active in the bloodstream for long, which is why it has such a short half-life.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Spontaneous hydrolysis: While spontaneous hydrolysis can occur, it is not the primary reason for adenosine's short half-life in vivo.

 

Option B. Rapid metabolism by enzymes in the liver: Although liver enzymes play a role in drug metabolism, in the case of adenosine, the rapid uptake and metabolism by RBCs and endothelial cells are more significant.

 

Option D. Renal excretion: While renal excretion does remove substances from the blood, adenosine's short half-life is due more to cellular uptake and metabolism than to excretion by the kidneys.

 

Educational objective:

 

Adenosine has a short half-life due to rapid uptake and intracellular metabolism in RBCs and endothelial cells, where it is phosphorylated to AMP or deaminated to eventually form uric acid. Adenosine is also the drug of choice (DOC) for the treatment of paroxysmal supraventricular tachycardia (PSVT).

choices.text: a & b
b & c
c & d
b & d

questions.text:
Drug obtained from plant (shown in the Figure) is used for treatment of?

 

 

  1. Myocardial infarction
  2. Malaria
  3. Congestive heart failure
  4. Arrhythmias
questions.solution:
Ans. D) b & d

 

Option D:

 

The image is identified as depicting the bark of the cinchona plant. From this plant, two significant drugs are derived: quinine and quinidine. Quinine has a long history of use in the treatment of malaria due to its antiprotozoal properties that are effective against the Plasmodium parasites causing the disease. Quinidine, a stereoisomer of quinine, is utilized in the medical field for its antiarrhythmic properties to treat various cardiac arrhythmias by acting on the heart's electrical conduction system to restore normal rhythm.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Myocardial infarction: Neither quinine nor quinidine is primarily used for the treatment of myocardial infarction.

 

Option B. Malaria: Quinine, obtained from the cinchona bark, is indeed used for the treatment of malaria.

 

Option C. Congestive heart failure: Neither quinine nor quinidine is a first-line treatment for congestive heart failure.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Quinine and quinidine, drugs derived from the cinchona plant, are used in the treatment of malaria and cardiac arrhythmias, respectively, illustrating the importance of plant-based compounds in the development of medications.

choices.text: It should be given in low doses to prevent hyperkalemia
It affords prognostic benefit in severe heart failure over and above ACEI
It helps to overcome refractoriness to loop diuretics
It affords rapid symptomatic relief in CHF patients

questions.text: All the following about the use of spironolactone in congestive heart failure are true except?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) It affords rapid symptomatic relief in CHF patients

 

Option D:

 

This statement is not typically true. While spironolactone can help manage symptoms of CHF by reducing fluid overload due to its diuretic effect, it does not provide rapid symptomatic relief. The primary effects of spironolactone in CHF are seen over a longer term, where it helps to manage fluid retention and provides benefits in terms of morbidity and mortality.

 

Based on these points, the statement that is not true about the use of spironolactone in CHF is d. It affords rapid symptomatic relief in CHF patients.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. It should be given in low doses to prevent hyperkalemia.

 

  • This statement is true. Spironolactone is a potassium-sparing diuretic, and one of its potential side effects is hyperkalemia (high blood potassium levels). Therefore, it is typically started at a low dose to minimize this risk.

 

Option B. It affords prognostic benefit in severe HF over and above ACEI.

 

  • This statement is true. Spironolactone has been shown to provide a prognostic benefit in patients with severe heart failure, reducing morbidity and mortality when added to standard therapy, including ACE inhibitors (ACEIs).

 

Option C. It helps to overcome refractoriness to loop diuretics.

 

  • This statement is true. Spironolactone can be used in combination with loop diuretics to overcome diuretic resistance in CHF. Loop diuretics can lead to increased renal potassium and magnesium loss, and adding a potassium-sparing agent like spironolactone can help counteract this effect and enhance diuretic response.

 

Current evidence suggests the following regarding aldosterone receptor antagonist (spironolactone and eplerenone) therapy in CHF:

 

  • It is indicated as add-on therapy to ACE inhibitors + other drugs in moderate-to-severe CHF.
  • It can retard disease progression, reduce episodes of decompensation and death due to heart failure as well as sudden cardiac deaths, over and above the protection afforded by ACE inhibitors/ARBs ± β blockers.
  • Only low doses (12.5–25 mg/day) of spironolactone should be used to avoid hyperkalemia; particularly because of concurrent ACE inhibitor/ARB therapy.
  • It may help restoration of diuretic response to furosemide when refractoriness has developed.

choices.text: Reduction of after load
Reduction of heart rate and cardiac MVO2
Reduction of preload and cardiac MVO2
Increase preload with decrease in cardiac MVO2

questions.text: Cardiac oxygen demand (MVO2) must be reduced in angina pectoris. The therapeutic rationale for using SL nitroglycerine is based on:
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Reduction of preload and cardiac MVO2

 

Option C:

 

  • Sublingual (SL) nitroglycerine acts primarily by dilating venous capacitance vessels, leading to a reduction in preload. By reducing preload, nitroglycerine decreases ventricular filling pressure and volume, which in turn reduces myocardial oxygen demand (MVO2). This mechanism helps alleviate angina pectoris by decreasing the workload on the heart and improving myocardial oxygen supply-demand balance.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Reduction of afterload: While nitroglycerine may have some effect on reducing afterload due to its arterial vasodilatory properties, its primary mechanism of action is the reduction of preload.

 

Option B. Reduction of heart rate and cardiac MVO2: Nitroglycerine may have a mild effect on heart rate, but its primary mechanism of action is not related to heart rate reduction. It mainly reduces preload, which indirectly decreases cardiac MVO2.

 

Option D. Increase preload with decrease in cardiac MVO2: Increasing preload would typically increase cardiac workload and oxygen demand rather than decrease it. This option contradicts the therapeutic rationale for using nitroglycerine in angina pectoris.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The educational goal is to understand the therapeutic rationale for using sublingual nitroglycerine in the management of angina pectoris. By reducing preload, nitroglycerine decreases myocardial oxygen demand, providing symptomatic relief in patients with angina. Understanding the mechanisms of action of nitroglycerine is essential for appropriate prescribing and management of angina episodes.

choices.text: These should be started at a very low dose and slowly titrated upwards
Carvedilol is the most widely used β blocker
These are drug of choice in acute decompensated heart failure
These can reduce mortality in CHF patients

questions.text: Which of the following is NOT true about the use of β blockers in CHF?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) These are drug of choice in acute decompensated heart failure

 

Option C:

 

Beta blockers are not the drug of choice in acute decompensated heart failure. In fact, they are contraindicated in this condition due to their potential to worsen the hemodynamic status. In acute decompensated heart failure, the goal is to quickly improve cardiac output and relieve symptoms, and the negative inotropic effects of beta blockers can counteract this goal.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. These should be started at a very low dose and slowly titrated upwards: This is correct and a key principle in the chronic management of CHF. Beta blockers need to be started at low doses to avoid abrupt changes in cardiac function and allow for patient tolerance.

 

Option B. Carvedilol is the most widely used β blocker: While carvedilol is one of the commonly used beta blockers in CHF, saying it is "the most widely used" may not be true in all settings, as metoprolol and bisoprolol are also commonly prescribed. However, this statement is generally accepted in practice.

 

Option D. These can reduce mortality in CHF patients: This is true. Beta blockers have been shown to decrease mortality in chronic CHF by improving left ventricular function, reducing arrhythmias, and limiting cardiac remodeling.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Beta blockers should not be used as the drug of choice in acute decompensated heart failure but are essential for the management of chronic CHF, where they have been shown to reduce mortality and morbidity.

choices.text: Losartan
Telmisartan
Candesartan
Olmesartan

questions.text: Angiotensin receptor blocker which blocks thromboxane A2 receptor is?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Losartan

 

Option A:

 

Losartan is the correct answer because it is not only an angiotensin receptor blocker (ARB) but also a competitive antagonist of the thromboxane A2 receptor. This dual action means that Losartan can block the effects of thromboxane A2, leading to an attenuation of platelet aggregation. Additionally, the metabolite of Losartan has the ability to reduce COX-2 mRNA upregulation and COX-dependent prostaglandin generation, which further contributes to its antiplatelet effects.

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. Telmisartan: Incorrect because Telmisartan is known as a partial agonist of peroxisome proliferator-activated receptor gamma (PPAR-γ), which differentiates it from Losartan and does not confer the ability to block the thromboxane A2 receptor.

 

Option C. Candesartan: Incorrect as Candesartan is an inactive ester prodrug that does not possess the ability to block the thromboxane A2 receptor. It is hydrolyzed to its active form within the body, which acts selectively on the angiotensin receptor.

 

Option D. Olmesartan: Incorrect for this question since Olmesartan, while also being an inactive ester prodrug hydrolyzed to its active form, does not block the thromboxane A2 receptor. It is cleared by renal elimination and biliary excretion and does not require dose adjustment in patients with mild-to-moderate renal or hepatic impairment.

 

Educational objective:

 

Losartan is unique among angiotensin receptor blockers in that it also competitively antagonizes the thromboxane A2 receptor, contributing to its antiplatelet effects.

choices.text: Aliskiren
Losartan
Perindopril
Vernakalant

questions.text: Which of the following is a direct renin inhibitor?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Aliskiren

 

Option A:

 

Aliskiren is a novel class of antihypertensive drug that works by directly inhibiting renin, an enzyme responsible for the conversion of angiotensinogen to angiotensin I (Ang I). This action effectively inhibits the renin-angiotensin-aldosterone system (RAAS) at its earliest step. Aliskiren is a low-molecular-weight, non-peptide molecule that acts as a potent competitive inhibitor of renin, reducing the production of angiotensin II (Ang II) as a result of the blocked conversion of angiotensinogen to Ang I.

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. Losartan: Losartan is an angiotensin II receptor blocker (ARB), which works further downstream in the RAAS pathway by blocking the angiotensin II type 1 receptors on blood vessels, leading to vasodilation.

 

Option C. Perindopril: Perindopril is an angiotensin-converting enzyme (ACE) inhibitor. It prevents the conversion of angiotensin I to angiotensin II by inhibiting the ACE enzyme.

 

Option D. Vernakalant: Vernakalant is not related to the RAAS pathway; it is a class III antiarrhythmic agent that acts as a multiple ion channel blocker, particularly affecting atrial cells, and is used to treat certain types of arrhythmias.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Aliskiren is the only direct renin inhibitor among the options listed, acting at the rate-limiting step of the RAAS pathway by inhibiting the conversion of angiotensinogen to angiotensin I.

choices.text: Hydralazine
Propranolol
Thiazide diuretic
Nifedipine

questions.text: A 33-year-old man is diagnosed with essential hypertension. He is started on an anti-hypertensive medication. After 6 weeks, he notes fatigue, rash over his face, joint aches, and effusions. A serum antinuclear antibody (ANA) test is positive. Which of the following is the most likely agent person was prescribed?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Hydralazine

 

Option A:

 

The patient's symptoms of fatigue, malar rash, joint pain, effusions, and a positive ANA test suggest the development of a drug-induced lupus erythematosus (SLE) like syndrome. Hydralazine is known to be associated with the development of drug-induced SLE. The condition is similar to idiopathic SLE and includes symptoms such as those described. Drug-induced SLE is reversible on stopping the offending agent.

 

Other options:

 

Option B. Propranolol: Beta-blockers like propranolol are not commonly associated with inducing a lupus-like syndrome.

 

Option C. Thiazide diuretic: Thiazide diuretics have various side effects but are not typically known to cause drug-induced lupus.

 

Option D.  Nifedipine: Nifedipine, a calcium channel blocker, is not associated with lupus-like symptoms.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Hydralazine is associated with the development of a lupus-like syndrome, which is characterized by symptoms such as rash, joint pain, fatigue, and positive ANA, and it is one of the drugs that can induce this condition, summarized by the acronym "SHIP" for sulfonamides, hydralazine, isoniazid, and procainamide.

 

The drugs causing SLE like syndrome include:

 

  • S: Sulfonamides (including dapsone)
  • H: Hydralazine
  • I: Isoniazid
  • P: Procainamide
    • All SHIP drugs are metabolized by acetylation.

choices.text: Triamterene
Atenolol
Clarithromycin
KCI

questions.text: A patient on digoxin therapy had a level of 1 ng/ml. He was receiving several other drugs and presented 2 months later with flattening of T waves in ECG. Now the plasma level of digoxin is 3.8 ng/ml. Which of the following drug is likely to be responsible?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Clarithromycin
 

Option C:

 

Clarithromycin is a macrolide antibiotic known to inhibit the P-glycoprotein transporter, which plays a role in the renal excretion of digoxin. Inhibition of this transporter leads to decreased renal clearance of digoxin, resulting in elevated plasma levels and potential digoxin toxicity. Flattening of T waves on ECG is a common manifestation of digoxin toxicity.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Triamterene: Triamterene is a potassium-sparing diuretic that can increase digoxin levels by reducing its renal clearance. However, the extent of increase observed in this case is less commonly associated with triamterene.

 

Option B. Atenolol: Atenolol, a beta-blocker, can increase digoxin levels by delaying its elimination. However, the degree of increase seen here is less characteristic of atenolol's interaction with digoxin.

 

Option D. KCl: Potassium chloride supplementation can potentiate the effects of digoxin, potentially leading to toxicity. However, it typically does not cause such a significant increase in digoxin levels.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Recognizing drug interactions that impact digoxin levels is crucial for preventing digoxin toxicity in patients receiving concurrent therapy. Vigilance and close monitoring of digoxin levels are essential to ensure patient safety.

 

INTERACTIONS OF DIGOXIN

 

  1. Hypokalemia, hypomagnesemia, and hypercalcemia may precipitate digoxin toxicity.
  2. Drugs causing digoxin toxicity include:
  • Quinidine
  • Verapamil
  • Amiodarone
  • Thiazides
  • Clarithromycin
  1. Renal failure predisposes to digoxin toxicity.

choices.text: Methyldopa
Labetalol
Lisinopril
Nifedipine

questions.text: A 26-year-old female came to hospital for preconception counseling. Patient is a known hypertensive compliant to drug therapy. Which of the following drugs will you advise to stop?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Lisinopril

 

Option C:

 

ACE Inhibitors (like lisinopril) and ARBs (like telmisartan) are known to be teratogenic and should be avoided if pregnancy is under consideration.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Methyldopa: Methyldopa is commonly used in pregnancy for hypertension and is considered safe. It is often continued during pregnancy if the patient is well-controlled.

 

Option B. Labetalol: Labetalol is another antihypertensive agent commonly used during pregnancy. It has a good safety profile and is often continued if the patient is well-controlled.

 

Option D. Nifedipine: Nifedipine is also considered safe for use during pregnancy and is commonly prescribed for hypertension in pregnant women.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Understanding the safety profiles of antihypertensive medications during pregnancy is essential for preconception counseling. Lisinopril is contraindicated during pregnancy due to its association with fetal malformations, particularly during the second and third trimesters. It is important to discontinue potentially harmful medications before conception to minimize risks to both the mother and the developing fetus.

 

SAFE ANTI-HYPERTENSIVES IN PREGNANCY

 

  • Better              - Beta blockers (Cardio selective and Labetalol)
  • Mother            - Methyldopa
  • Care                 -Clonidine
  • During             -Dihydropyridine CCB (sustained release nifedipine, amlodipine)
  • Hypertensive   - Hydralazine
  • Pregnancy       - Prazosin (and other alpha blockers)

choices.text: Quinidine
Lignocaine
Ciprofloxacin
Propranolol

questions.text: Which of the following drugs can result in prolongation of QT interval in ECG?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Quinidine

 

Option A:

 

Quinidine is a class Ia anti-arrhythmic drug that acts by blocking Na+ (sodium) and K+ (potassium) channels. The blocking of potassium channels is particularly important in the context of the question as it can affect the repolarization phase of the cardiac action potential, which is reflected as QT interval on an electrocardiogram (ECG). Prolonged repolarization leads to a prolonged QT interval, which can predispose to a type of ventricular tachycardia called Torsades de Pointes, a potentially life-threatening condition.

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. Lignocaine: Lignocaine (also known as lidocaine) is a class Ib anti-arrhythmic drug that predominantly blocks Na+ channels and is less likely to cause QT prolongation as its action is more specific to the fast sodium channels and it actually tends to shorten the action potential duration.

 

Option C. Ciprofloxacin: Ciprofloxacin is a fluoroquinolone antibiotic. Although fluoroquinolones like sparfloxacin, levofloxacin, and moxifloxacin are associated with QT prolongation, ciprofloxacin is less implicated in causing this adverse effect when compared to other drugs in its class.

 

Option D. Propranolol: Propranolol is a non-selective beta-blocker and is not commonly associated with QT prolongation. It acts on the beta-adrenergic receptors and can affect heart rate and contractility but not typically the QT interval.

 

Educational objective:

 

Quinidine, a class Ia anti-arrhythmic drug, can cause QT interval prolongation on an ECG due to its blockade of potassium channels, which affects the repolarization phase of the cardiac action potential.

choices.text: Alpha 1
Alpha 2
Beta 1
Beta 2

questions.text: Inotropic drugs act by stimulating which of the following receptors?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Beta 1

 

Inotropic drugs often act by stimulating beta 1 adrenergic receptors. Beta 1 receptors are primarily found in the heart, and when they are stimulated, they increase myocardial contractility (the force of contraction) and heart rate. This action is beneficial in treating certain conditions like heart failure, where an increase in cardiac output is needed.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The educational goal is to understand the mechanism of action of different inotropic drugs.

 

INOTROPICS DRUGS

 

  1. Beta 1 agonists
  • Dopamine
  • Dobutamine
  • Nor-adrenaline
  • Isoprenaline

 

  1. Phosphodiesterase inhibitors
  • Inamrinone
  • Milrinone
  • Levosimendan

 

  1. Cardiac glycosides
  • Digoxin
  • Digitoxin (withdrawn now)

choices.text: Inhibition of HMG-CoA reductase
Inhibition of cholesterol absorption in the small intestine
Inhibition of bile acid synthesis in the liver
Inhibition of lipoprotein lipase activity

questions.text: Which of the following is the mechanism of action of ezetimibe for the treatment of hypercholesterolemia?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Inhibition of cholesterol absorption in the small intestine

 

Option B:

 

Ezetimibe specifically targets the NPC1L1 (Niemann-Pick C1-Like 1) protein, which is involved in the intestinal absorption of cholesterol. By inhibiting NPC1L1, ezetimibe reduces the uptake of cholesterol in the small intestine, leading to a decrease in the amount of cholesterol delivered to the liver. This results in a reduction of hepatic cholesterol stores and an increase in clearance of cholesterol from the blood; consequently, LDL cholesterol levels in the bloodstream decrease.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Inhibition of HMG-CoA reductase: This is the mechanism of action for statins, not ezetimibe. Statins inhibit the rate-limiting step in cholesterol synthesis in the liver.

 

Option C. Inhibition of bile acid synthesis in the liver: Bile acid sequestrants work by this mechanism. They bind bile acids in the intestine, leading to increased excretion of cholesterol in the feces.

 

Option D. Inhibition of lipoprotein lipase activity: Inhibiting lipoprotein lipase would prevent the breakdown of triglycerides, not cholesterol. This is not a mechanism associated with ezetimibe.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Ezetimibe reduces LDL cholesterol by inhibiting the absorption of cholesterol in the small intestine through its action on the NPC1L1 protein.
